As observed in archeological sites, population in Northern Africa decreased between 6,300–5,200 years ago[113] over less than a millennium,[607] beginning from the north.[635] In inner Arabia many settlements were abandoned about 5,300 years ago.[391] Some Neolithic people in the desert persisted for longer thanks to the exploitation of groundwater.[549]

Different human populations responded to the drying in diverse manners,[318] with responses in the Western Sahara being distinct from those in the Central Sahara.[8] In the Central Sahara, pastoralism replaced hunter-gatherer activity[636] and a more nomadic lifestyle replaced semi-sedentary lifestyles[637] as observed in the Acacus Mountains of Libya.[301] Nomadic lifestyles also developed in the Eastern Sahara/Red Sea Hills in response to the end of the AHP.[638] There was a shift in domestic animal use from cattle to sheep and goats as these are more suited in arid climates, a change reflected in rock art from which cattle disappeared at this time.[639]

The development of irrigation systems in Arabia may have been an adaptation to the drying tendency.[359] The decreased availability of resources forced human populations to adapt,[640] in general fishing and hunting declined in favour of farming and herding.[641] However, the effects of the end of the AHP on human food production have been subject to controversy.[642]

The warm episode and coinciding drought may have triggered animal and human migration to less inhospitable areas[584] and the appearance of pastoralists where previously fishery-dependent societies had existed, as happened at Lake Turkana.[384] Humans moved to the Nile, where the society of Ancient Egypt with pharaohs and pyramids was eventually forged by these climate refugees[607][643][644] perhaps reflecting renewed exuberance;[323] thus the end of the AHP can be considered responsible for the birth of Ancient Egypt.[1][644] Lower water levels in the Nile also aided the settlement of its valley as has been observed at Kerma.[645] A similar process may have led to the development of the Garamantian civilization.[646] Such human migrations towards more hospitable conditions along rivers and the development of irrigation also took place along the Euphrate, Tigris and Indus, leading to the development of the Sumerian and Harappan civilizations.[58][647] Population shifts into mountain areas have also been reported for the Air Mountains, Hoggar and Tibesti.[465] In other places, such as the Acacus Mountains populations conversely remained in oases[553][648] and hunter-gatherers also stayed in the Horn of Africa.[148]

The Nile itself was not totally unaffected however;[376] the 4.2 kiloyear event[649] and the end of the AHP may be linked to the collapse of the Old Kingdom in Egypt[24] when the Nile floods failed for three decades around 4,160 years before present.[650] The ongoing decrease of precipitation after the end of the AHP could be the cause of the end of the Akkadian Kingdom in Mesopotamia.[651] The end of the Garamantian civilization may also relate to climate change although other historical events were probably more important;[652] at Tanezzuft oasis after 1,600 years ago it certainly relates to the drying trend.[648]

In Central Africa, forests became discontinuous and savannahs formed in some places, facilitating the movement and growth of Bantu speaking populations;[603] these in turn may have affected the ecosystem.[653] The vegetation changes may have aided in the establishment of agriculture.[618] The relatively slow decline of precipitation gave humans more time to adapt to the changing climate conditions.[411]

Cultural changes may also have occurred as a consequence of climate change, such as[654] changes in gender roles, the development of elites,[655] the increased presence of human burials where formerly cattle burials predominated,[656] as well as an increase of monumental architecture in the Sahara may have also been a response to increasingly adverse climates.[636] A spread in cattle domestication at the time of climate change[301] and as herders escaped the drying Sahara southwards[657][658] may also relate to these events, although the details of the exact process by which cattle domestication spread are still controversial.[654] Finally, changes in agricultural practices at the end of the AHP may be associated with the propagation of malaria and one of its causative pathogens Plasmodium falciparum; in turn these may correlate with the origin of human genome variants such as sickle cell disease that are linked to malaria resistance.[659]

Non-human

In the Sahara, animal and plant populations were fragmented and restricted to certain favoured areas such as moist areas of mountain ranges; this happened for example to fish and crocodiles which only persist in isolated water bodies. Mediterranean plants[660][661] such as cypresses too persist only in mountains,[662] along with some reptiles that may have also been stranded in mountains by the drying.[663] The whip spider Musicodamon atlanteus is probably also a relic of past wetter conditions.[664] The buffalo species Syncerus antiquus probably went extinct from the increased competition of pastoralists triggered by the climate drying.[665] The drying of the African Great Lakes region split gorilla populations became split into western and eastern populations,[403] and a similar population split between the insect species Chalinus albitibialis and Chalinus timnaensis in Northern Africa and the Middle East may have also been caused by the expansion of deserts there.[666] Giraffes, widespread in the Sahara during the AHP, may have been forced to migrate into the Sahel; this together with the separating effect of Lake Megachad may have influenced the development of giraffe subspecies.[667] Climate change together with human impacts may have led to the extinction of a number of large mammals in Egypt.[668]

The Dahomey Gap[669] formed 4,500–3,200 years before present, correlative to the end of the AHP.[670] The harbour porpoise declined in the Mediterranean due to a switch to oligotrophic conditions as discharge from African rivers decreased.[441] Desert varnish formed on exposed rocks in the Sahara.[671]

Global climate

The shrinkage of subtropical wetlands probably led to a drop in atmospheric methane concentrations between 5,500 and 5,000 years ago, before boreal wetlands expanded and offset the loss of subtropical wetlands, leading to a return of higher atmospheric methane concentrations.[503] Conversely, increases in atmospheric methane concentrations, detected in Greenland ice cores about 14,700 years ago,[83] and atmospheric carbon dioxide decreases in the early Holocene may relate to the vegetation expansion caused by the AHP.[672] Carbon dioxide concentration then increased after about 7,000 years as the biosphere began releasing carbon in response to increasing aridity.[651]

A sudden increase in the amount of land-originating dust in an oceanic drill core off Cape Blanc, Mauritania, has been interpreted as reflecting the end of the AHP 5,500 years ago occurring in only a few centuries.[673] Potentially, dried up lake basins became an important source for dust.[103][570] Today, the Sahara is the single largest source of dust in the world, with far ranging effects on climate and ecosystems,[674] such as the growth of the Amazon rainforest.[675]

The period 5,500–5,000 years ago also witnessed major changes in global climate, including the onset of global cooling in the form of the Neoglacial.[676] In one climate model, the desertification of the Sahara at the end of the AHP reduces the amount of heat transported in the atmosphere and ocean towards the poles, inducing cooling of 1–2 °C (1.8–3.6 °F) especially in winter in the Arctic and an expansion of sea ice. Reconstructed temperatures in the Arctic indeed show a cooling, although less pronounced than in the climate model.[677] Further, this climate transition in the climate model is accompanied by increased negative Arctic Oscillation states, a weaker subpolar gyre and increased precipitation and cold air outbreaks in much of Europe; such changes have also been observed in paleoclimate data.[678] These findings imply that the vegetation state of the Sahara influences the Northern Hemisphere climate.[679] In turn, this high latitude cooling may have further reduced precipitation over Africa.[611]

7. Present-Day Situation

Presently, the African Monsoon still influences the climate between 5° south and 25° north latitude; the latitudes around 10° north receive the bulk of their precipitation from the monsoon[680] during summer, with smaller amounts of rainfall occurring farther north. Thus farther north deserts can be found while the moister areas are vegetated.[114] In the Central Sahara, annual precipitation reaches no more than 50–100 millimetres per year (2.0–3.9 in/year).[681] Even farther north, the margin of the desert coincides with the area where the westerlies bring precipitation;[2] they also influence southernmost Africa.[682] Subsidence of air over parts of Northern Africa is responsible for the existence of deserts, which is further increased by the radiative cooling over the desert.[1] Climate variability exists to this day, with the Sahel suffering from droughts in the 1970s and 1980s when precipitation decreased by 30% and the flow of the Niger River and Senegal River even more,[683] followed by an increase of precipitation.[1]

In East Africa the monsoon leads to two rain seasons in the equatorial area, the so-called "long rains" in March–May and the "short rains" in October–November[684] when the ITCZ moves northward and southward over the region, respectively;[685] in addition to the Indian Ocean-sourced precipitation there is also Atlantic[686]- and Congo-sourced precipitation west of the Congo Air Boundary.[684][687] In Arabia, the monsoon does not penetrate far from the Arabian Sea and some areas are under the influence of winter precipitation brought by cyclones from the Mediterranean Sea.[688] East Africa is also under the influence of monsoon circulations.[689]

8. Implications for Future Global Warming

Some simulations of global warming and increased carbon dioxide concentrations have shown a substantial increase in precipitation in the Sahel/Sahara. This could lead to an expansion of vegetation into present-day desert, although it would be less extensive than during the mid-Holocene[111] and perhaps accompanied by a northward shift of the desert, i.e. a drying of northernmost Africa.[690] Such a precipitation increase may also reduce the amount of dust originating in Northern Africa,[691] with effects on hurricane activity in the Atlantic and increased threats of hurricane strikes in the Caribbean, the Gulf of Mexico and the East Coast of the United States of America.[471]

The Special Report on Global Warming of 1.5 °C and the IPCC Fifth Assessment Report indicate that global warming will likely result in increased precipitation across most of East Africa, parts of Central Africa and the principal wet season of West Africa, although there is significant uncertainty related to these projections especially for West Africa.[692] In addition, the end of the 20th century drying trend may be due to global warming.[693] On the other hand, West Africa[694] and parts of East Africa may become drier during given seasons and months.[693][694] Currently, the Sahel is becoming greener but precipitation has not fully recovered to levels reached in the mid-20th century.[690]

Climate models have yielded equivocal results about the effects of anthropogenic global warming on the Sahara/Sahel precipitation. Human-caused climate change occurs through different mechanisms than the natural climate change that led to the AHP.[695] One study in 2003 showed that vegetation intrusions in the Sahara can occur within decades after strong rises in atmospheric carbon dioxide[696] but would not cover more than about 45% of the Sahara.[27] That climate study also indicated that vegetation expansion can only occur if grazing or other perturbations to vegetation growth do not hamper it.[697]
